parts.text: Identify the following breeds from the list Breed A: Blackface mountain Breed B: Large white Breed C: Saddleback Breed D: Suffolk Breed E: Texel
(i) Identify the following breeds of cattle shown. Breed A: Limousine Breed B: Charolais Breed C: Hereford Breed D: Aberdeen Angus
(ii) Beef breeds have a rectangular conformation. Explain the underlined term – The shape of the animal, making reference to structure and appearance

subparts.text: The shape of the animal, making reference to structure and appearance

parts.text: (i) Identify each of the following plants which are often found on Irish farms. PLANT A : PLANT B : PLANT C: Thistle Ragwort Cow parsley (accept spear thistle)

subparts.text: (ii) Outline two ways that farmers can prevent the build up of weeds on their farms Any two valid s:
solution: Having crops in fields rather than allow them to lie fallow

parts.text: Describe with the aid of a labelled diagram how to determine the soil texture of a soil sample by sedimentation. Any four valid points 4 x 2m = 8m 2m for correct labelled diagram 10m in total
solution: Add soil sample to a beaker with water in it and stir using glass rod
Add this suspension to a graduated cylinder
Place a stopper on top of graduated cylinder and shade mixture
Leave for 1-2 days and Observe the layers that form
Record volume of each layer and then calculate the percentage of sand, silt and clay present in sample
Use the soil triangle to identify the type of soil present

parts.text: Complete the sentences below using words from the list.
Explain why each of the principles are important in optimising soil health
Name the sector that had the greatest income from exports in 2023.
Name the sector that had the lowest income from exports in 2023.
Prepared Consumer Foods created €3.1 billion for the Irish economy in 2023. Explain why there would be such a demand for these foods Any one valid reason (2m)
solution: Good availability of food in supermarkets
Nutritional information provided on package which appeals to consumers

parts.text: Is the data shown in this chart qualitative or quantitative data? Tick the correct . 2m for quantitative Quantitative data 

Is the data presented from a reliable source? Give a reason for your Yes (1m) Any valid reason (1m) − Numerical data shown/ − Scientific terminology used / − Irish Farmers Journal are a reliable source as they employ vets and scientists

Read the following passage and the questions that follow. (i) State two consequences of sheep presenting with blowfly. Any two valid s 2 x 1m = (2m) – skin irritation/ – pain/ – secondary bacterial infections on the sheep/ – increase in veterinary costs for the farmer/ – loss in animal production.

subparts.text: Why do blowflies lay eggs on sheep? Blowflies lay eggs on sheep as the fleece acts as a nice incubator for the eggs and larva (maggots) to develop
How could a farmer prevent blowfly strike in their flock? Any one valid (2m) – Good hygiene/ – Use of insecticides/ – Shearing sheep/ – Dagging/ – Tail docking/

parts.text: Distinguish between the underlined terms. 2m for each correct explanation (2 x 2m = 4m) Dagging: the removal of wool around the tail area to prevent the build up of faeces and infection Docking: shortening of the sheep tail to prevent infections
(b) the following questions on animal genetics (i) What is genetic modification? (2m) Altering an organism's DNA for the purpose of improvement or to correct a defect in the organism.
solution: Altering an organism's DNA for the purpose of improvement or to correct a defect in the organism.

subparts.text: (ii) List one potential benefit and one potential risk of using genetic modification in animal production. Benefits – any one valid (2m) – Increased disease resistance/ – Enhanced growth rates and productivity/ – New animal products created / – Increased prolificacy/ – Improved feed conversion efficiency/
(iii) Discuss the ethical issues relating to animal genetics. Any one valid (4m) – Animal welfare/ – Animal health and spread of disease/ – New strains of disease spreading and affecting animals/
solution: Animal health and spread of disease
New strains of disease spreading and affecting animals

parts.text: How might the decrease in strawberry production affect consumers and the market? Any one valid reason (2m)
solution: Increase in cost due to supply issues

parts.text: What are some potential solutions for farmers like Jimmy facing similar weather-related challenges?
Sandy soils are commonly found in southerly counties such as Wexford. Why are sandy soils favourable for crop production?
solution: Large pore space so air and water can move

context: Read the following article published by Teagasc and use the information in it to answer the questions that follow.

parts.text: What percentage of Ireland’s total agricultural output is made up of beef farming?
What is the total size of the national breeding herd in Ireland?
In 2020, what percentage of Ireland’s beef production was exported?
What factors give Ireland a competitive advantage in beef farming?
solution: Ability to produce large quantities of grass for animals

parts.text: What was the average suckler income in 2021 and what was a significant source of this income?
solution: €10,927; derived from direct support payments like CAP

parts.text:
Explain the underlined terms in the extract above. 4m each (2 x 4m = 8m)
Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) – The agricultural policy of the EU/ – Implements a system of subsides and financial supports for farmers – **Accept other appropriate s
Sustainability – This means it will last into the future for future generations

Greenhouse gases (GHG) are referred to in the article. Give one example of a Greenhouse gas that affects the environment. Any one valid 2m – Carbon dioxide (CO ) 2 – Methane (CH ) 4 – Nitrous oxide (N O)

Grass is one of the most popular crops on farms that animals eat and it has many benefits. Outline two of these benefits 2 x 2m = 4m – Grass-based beef production systems are more sustainable as they have a low – Lower carbon footprint. – Distinct flavour of meat. – High CLA have beneficial health effects.

(b) (i) Beef farmers must carefully select animals with desirable traits to get good produce from these animals. List 3 desirable traits that a beef farmer looks for in animals. Any three traits (3 x 2m = 6m)
– Good fertility/
– High milk yields/
– Calving ease/
– Long life span /
– High calf survival rates/
– Conformation/
– Good hindquarters/
– Long back/
– Wide torso/
**Accept other appropriate s

(ii) Good breeding strategies are also needed on beef farms to allow for offspring with desirable traits to be produced. The use of a stock bull and A.I. (artificial insemination) are two methods commonly used by beef farmers. For each method state one advantage and one disadvantage. 2m for each correct advantage and disadvantage (4 x 2m = 8m)
Stock bull
Advantages Disadvantages
• Bull on farm so has easy access to cows
• Dangerous
• No extra cost to farmer for repeat
• Experienced person needed inseminations
• Expensive initially to purchase bull
• Only one breed can be used on farm
• Inbreeding may occur

(iii) Outline the management of a beef calf from birth to 6 weeks under the following headings: 4m for each heading (3 x 4m = 12m)
Feeding management:
– Access to fresh water/
– Colostrum given at birth – up to 2L in forts 3 hours/
– Calf left with mother to get milk/
– Milk replacer may be needed if cow if not producing enough milk initially
– **Accept other valid points Housing management:
– Housed with mother/
– Straw bedding/
– Adequate space in pens/
– Adequate lighting in shed/
– Well ventilated to prevent infection / Health management:
– Spray navel with iodine or disinfectant to prevent navel ill/
– Tagged within 20 days/
– Tested for BVD/
– Registered on AIM system /
– Dehorn within 3 weeks/
